Posts.Content: That is excellent news    I will be 4 years in January  It is a bit of a hard journey at times but like you Helen I too can confirm that there really is life after BC  I work full time ,enjoy family life and am a glass full person about what the future holds June
Posts.Title: 4 years on

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed in Jan 2012 and because I was HR2+ had to have Herceptin which meant that I had to have chemo which I would not have had were it not for the Herceptin   As we all know this is a  s**t  experience and awful but and this is my point : I feel privileged to have received this treatment and I know of others with the same diagnosis who 2 -3 years earlier did not get offered this . In fact Herceptin was very much a post-code lottery with a number of Health Trusts refusing to pay. Yet here I am benefitting so much from what I know is a very expensive treatment    Surely others would agree that this applies to these other drugs Take Care June
Posts.Title: Breast cancer drugs stopped by Mr Cameron

Posts.Content: Initally I was told something simlar .I had clear margins and no lymph node involvement As i was trying to make up my mind I then was told I was HER2 and therefore I needed to have chemo anyway I had already decided to have it and it was tough but doable I am now 18months post chemo and nearly 12 post Herceptin My hair has been slow and has grown back   I guess it is all relative If you have the choice then mine would be to throw everything at it I believe developping this is outwith our control ( despite the hype on the news) but making proactive decsions where we can is somethng we can control     Good Luck with whatever you decide   J x
Posts.Title: Chemo decision. Yes or no?

Posts.Content: I think it is such an individual decision I was off for 7 months after lumpectomy chemo and radiotherapy I went back while continuing with Herceptin treatment. I had supportive employers and a phased return. My job is extremely busy and initially I found I was shattered and coming straight home and going to sleep I was so exhausted With hindsight I might have done 2 things a bit differently I would have taken more time before returning and used that time to build some stamina. I also would have worked maybe a 4 as opposed to a 5 day week for longer to help with the tiredness I have been back for 7 months full time and some weeks I am still really tired. It is getting better but after all our bodies go through it is not surprising that getting back to work is much harder than first imagined If you can be really kind to yourself Good Luck June
Posts.Title: Going back to work

Posts.Content: I think it has todend on so many factors. I went back to work in a really demanding job after my second chemo. There is no way to predict the demands on me and I also had a 24 hourly change of a syringe driver for sickness for the first 10 days of chemo I really tried it after but 4 weeks my boss spoke to me about how concerned my staff were as they passed by my office as I had my head on my desk taking a sleep. I was persuaded that I focus everything on dealing with treatment and for me this was exactly right. That said I believe I really needed to try and am glad I did Play it by ear and go with how you get on. Good luck with whatever you decide June
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and work

Posts.Content: I was so glad to have finished chemo so thought that RTX would be so much easier. I was surprised to find how exhausted I felt. Kate's advice is so good. Let this last bit take its course as you cannot rush your body Eat well ,drink loads and exercise and sleep where you can and want to. Well done for getting to this point Jx
Posts.Title: Post Radiotherapy exhaustion

Posts.Content: I got a combined chemo plus Herceptin so was in Chemo Unit for 5 hours at a time my hubby was with me and I really appreciated company and general support. I did and could drive but having someone there was really good Take Care June
Posts.Title: driving

Posts.Content: I went to LGFB almost 18 months ago. In Dumfries we have to go to hospital in Edinburgh75 miles away and stay in a hostel in the grounds together daily radiotherapy. I went to a Maggie Centre aged 56 I learned how to properly put make on for the first time in my life. I use the same good products now and the techniques they taught me are used every day It was a high spot in what was a very low week away from home. I met others like me and left feeling fab A wonderful resource. Enjoy June
Posts.Title: Look Good Feeling Better

Posts.Content: Hi I am sorry I don't have a solution but I am exactly in the same position I have tried both and am on Anastrozole now but don't find it any better. My GP did a blood test which confirmed my joint /bone pain and also confirmed it was not arthritis. I find that I am really bad first thing but then my onset can be a bit random in terms of when and how. I also need to be moving about and sometimes I find the pain really gets me down. I have heard or read that this can go over time but have not found a good solution to this at all and I have done a year so far. I would be really interested if anyone has got any thoughts or suggestions Take Care June
Posts.Title: Letrozole/Anastrozole side effects

Posts.Content: I was determined to work through chemo after surgery. On my second cycle I returned to a very busy and demanding job I had a syringe driver with anti sickness meds in my chest which I tried to disguise with scarves and which needed changed every 24 hours. The hospital was 5 minutes from work and I went there got the syringe changed and went to work. Although folks were lovely once at work it is full on and I really struggled but thought it would get better. Eventually after 3 weeks I had to admit defeat and the best thing I did was to focus on me and getting better. However being career minded and after finishing rads I went back I started on a phased return but within 4 weeks i would literally sit in hospital getting Herceptin while working on my iPad and before driving to work To be honest I agree everyone needs to go with what feels right for them but it is nearly one and half years since I started back and I am still pretty knackered and trying to cope with the effects of Anastrozole. Being focused on work helped in some ways but at the end of the day health is more important and I think I learned that the hard way Happy New Year to all J x
Posts.Title: Back to work?

Posts.Content: Hi there As has already been said everyone is different. I found for me that the treatment and the side effects made a routine which my body had to follow. So the first week was a bit of a write off the second better and the third normal. So I did things and stocked up with shopping etc when I felt well and took it easy and lived off what I had stored up when I needed to. Ginger helped with taste and sickness and pineapple with mouth problems. I made ice lollies from pineapple which I used when desired. Right now it might feel ovwhelming but take heart if you can from other posts and Kate's message is so true. There is a really excellent survival rate Take Care June
Posts.Title: Feeling sad and alone :(

Posts.Content: I did not know this and am on Anastrozole having stopped letrozole for the same reasons I suffer badly from bone and muscle pain and the joints in my right had are almost immobile or have so little mobility that things slip form my grasp My GP is considering another type of medication but as he said there could simply be different but equally challenging side effects I am the only wage earner and find at week ends I tend to do little as I am almost resting up to start wrok in the coming week I would be really intersted if you or anyone has discovered a less problematic medication
Posts.Title: Generic Anastrazole - any brand better than another and right old...

Posts.Content: OMG. It feels like a light bulb moment reading these posts. I went back to work in September last year one month after finishing rads which were preceded by chemo and surgery. I was still having Herceptin and getting it in the morning then straight to work in the afternoon I so wanted normality and struggled with real tiredness ,aches and pains( which I now realise are down to Anastrozole ) and a constant felling that I should be feeling normal or my old self. This is something I have just not managed. I realise that I now am struggling with what has happened to me and during my treatments I got on with it mainly cos you don't have a choice but now everyone thinks I am all better and fixed It really helps to know you are not alone but how do we manage these feelings and get on with the business of living fully in the present Jx
Posts.Title: All Done ... So what am I ??

Posts.Content: Hi  I have just been for what is my 5 year mammogram ( diagnosed in Jan 12 ) I had a lumpectomy chemo: herceptin and rads and am still on anastrozole ( and just about coping) I initially did not want to consider getting my left breast sorted as quite frankly the thought of anything else was off putting I am assuming ( and i hope i have not jinxed it ) that this mammogram is fine and my benchmark of 5 years has come and gone  However my left breast has become more deformed over time and actually  feel as if *I could face putting it right" but am not sure what that entails   It was quite a big lumpectomy in the bottom inner quadrant and my breast and the nipple have turned in on themselves and are really misshapen now  Anyone had this type done  PS the positive is that 5 years have gone by , I am fit and well and am still working full time managing all life brings  Good luck to all still on their own journeys  June
Posts.Title: Reconstructive work 5 years after original lumpectomy

Posts.Content: I am or rather was a workaholic and also the main breadwinner. I was determined to return to work during chemo and did very briefly I could not keep up (chemo brain)and concerned colleagues would pass by my office and I was asleep with my head on the desk. After 2 weeks my boss very kindly asked me if I thought this was working and helped me see that I needed all my focus and strength to fight and get well So I stopped work and concentrated on dealing with the treatments. However with the same lack of thought I returned 4 weeks after radiotherapy while having Herceptin treatment While I have managed I recognise that this has not been a sensible decision and like everyone says health and family are much more important Pauline please look after yourself June
Posts.Title: guilty not working

Posts.Content: I had anti sickness meds on a syringe driver I had it inserted on the day of chemo and changed every 24 hours for 10 days. For me this meant an hour each morning going up to hospital but it was so so worth it and I virtually stopped being sick and had all my chemo. Take care and big cyber hugs June xxx
Posts.Title: Syringe driver for anti sickness meds

Posts.Content: I am so sorry to hear of your terrible time. Bad enough dealing with BC without feeling your treatment is being visited by the F*** Up Fairy I live in Dumfries and for my Rads had to live in a hospital hostel in Edinburgh for 4 weeks. I have to say every part of my treatment from diagnosis to surgery chemo rads and Herceptin was so very positive You deserve and should demand better. Please take care and good luck June
Posts.Title: Not so great experiences with NHS - good news stories please!

Posts.Content: I am one year on from my last rads and my hair although thick is still very short even though I get a wee bit trimmed to try and keep it in shape. I used to wear my hair short and spiky and if truth be told i suit it like that. However I get frustrated because i want to have trhe choice ,hence my impatirnce at how very long this takes to grow.I can look back and see that it HAS grown and have never really liked my wigs so went au natural at work since September when I had some fuzz.so my progress has been charted by Colleagues   I remind my self ( or try to) that in the scheme of things its not so bad and have recently jazzed it up with some bright colours . Hug to everyone june
Posts.Title: How soon will I get some hair?

Posts.Content: I can also relate to breast pain and am 2 years post op. I was told by my breast consultant that this is a mixture of the effects of surgery and radiotherapy. I agree with Dorothee that as mine is just there but not impacting on my day to day living I just accept it as part of me. However at first I sought reassurance from my consultant and would suggest you check it out if worried or need help the pain. J s
Posts.Title: breast pain

Posts.Content: I do not know what I can say I too have been helped by your posts. Take care Jx
Posts.Title: It's Back! And this time it's...

Posts.Content: I had a scare last year one month before my 1st annual check up My amazing breast consultant chide me for not phoning her clinic directly and after reassuring me I was ok toLd me in future never to wait or worry but to get an immediate appointment if I was the slightest bit worried. A month later I had my routine annual check up and mammogram. I was told that they usually sent the results by post in the normal way I was asked to wait and after a few minutes the consultant radiographer appeared and said all looked clear and I think this was specifically because she had diagnosed me last year and knew how important this was. In April after my final Herceptin I saw the oncologist who after telling me after her examination that all was well told me after I asked her about my specific odds for the future what my predicted outlook was which I must say looks pretty pretty good. I don't suppose I will ever not have that bit of doubt each year but all of the people I mentioned are all on my side and I have beaten this awful thing before and I have a good outlook I will try and hold onto that at each check up as a kind of charm Hugs to all June
Posts.Title: 12 month check up - scared !

Posts.Content: I had to live in a hostel in the grounds of The Western General in Edinburgh from Monday to Friday for 4 weeks to get my rads as there are no facilities in Dumfries which is 2 hours away. I attended a LGFB session there and it was the best part of the whole month Also my usual make up when I did wear it was probably 10 years old and at 56 I learned the art of applying make up and now use really good products and my new skills every working day. This was such an unexpected bonus and to be helped to look your best when you feel at your worst is amazing For anyone who gets the chance go and enjoy Take Care J
Posts.Title: Look Good, Feel Better

Posts.Content: Well done for taking control. BC takes most of our control away so when I had mine shaved off just before I started chemo I fel oddly liberated too. The wigs are not bad and the au naturel look is cool. I personally used scarves and hats and enjoyed making my look my way. You Tube has nifty video clips on how to tie scarves etc. My last chemo was a year ago and I finished rads 11 months ago. I now have hair again when exactly a year ago I was at my niece's wedding wearing my wig ( which looks ok on the pictures) At the time it can seem so very devastating but this time passes Stay positive June x
Posts.Title: well I finally did it! !

Posts.Content: My hair grew back a wee bit differently. It was pretty much the same colour which disappointed me as lots say you get more grey which I wanted and a chance to go light or blonde. However it is still mostly dark brown It is much thicker although it is growing is very slow . My wonderful friend who teaches hairdressing at the College where I work has looked after me from shaving my head and now to coaxing new albeit short styles . She has dyed it using safer dyes and slowly but surely it is coming good. I am in Scotland but while I was having rads was lucky enough to attend a workshop run by the Maggie Centres which shows how to put your face on including dealing with little or no eyebrows etc. I think they are available throughout the country and some are delivered at local hospitals. I think they are called Look Good Feel Better and really helped with confidence etc Good Luck June
Posts.Title: well I finally did it! !

Posts.Content: I well remember that feeling and also feeling that it was so unfair that I had endured a lot of treatments and now somehow should be so much better For me it was time and despite all of the other things it was the passing of time and having a bit of patience especially with myself that helped I am 3 years on   I am now working full time in a very demanding job . I swim at weekends and walk my dogs.  Am I back to where I was before? ,Maybe not quite. My bones and joints hurt and that is the armidex but I am determined to keep taking it  I do some things different and am knitting and reading more  Be kind to yourself   As you put more distance between that awful time things will gradually seem better  You are still healing and recovering  Take Care June
Posts.Title: when does this end.....

Posts.Content: Hi I am in Dumfries and attended the breast clinic at 9 and was told by 12 30 I had breast cancer and I had a needle biopsy. What I did not know till later was the details that it was positive for oestrogen and her2 till later. I guess it depends on the hospital but I know mine was brilliant at every stage. Wishing you good luck. Take Care June
Posts.Title: Bruising after lymph node removal

Posts.Content: I think losing hair and getting the wig somehow makes the diagnosis and impending treatments so real and likewise the re growing of our hair no matter how slow kind of symbolises the recovery I ended up not wearing mine except for a few occasions and got quite into lots of scarves and big earrings and making my new but temporary look The thing is this is temporary and like aroma mum says you will get through it . I think some partners don't know how to react but if you need to cry then you surely are entitled As a little aside at 57 I ended up in our local press last week dressed as a tree with leaves coming out of my hair as part of an event at work. When I expressed my horror my family said that in less than a year I had come a long way as 10 months ago I was a bald woman "dressing up" in a wig. LOL which put things in perspective Please take care Patricia and all of us who have experienced what you are going through will understand J. X
Posts.Title: emotions

Posts.Content: In Jan 2012 I had a WLE . I had chemo .RT and Herceptin and 5 years Anastrozole and now in 5 years tamoxifen . I might be unusal with this part of my issue. My tumor was almost 3 cm and was removed from my left breast ,just under my nipple slighltly to theright part of my breast. In the beginning I was too busy coming to grips with chemo etc then getting back to work   At my 1st and 2nd year all clear I was offered reconstruction in the form of sucking fat from my body and injecting it into my breast  I was understandably not keen to have anything else out into my breast even if it was from a part of me  . I am so lucky and had my 5 year all clear earlier this year   I am now coping at work and swimming and walking my dogs . However recently I have had problems with this breast  My surgery initaly made my breast look as if it had an inverted nipple . Now this nipple is firmly tucked into my breast ( in the space where this tumour was) I have had infections recently where both blood and pus have emanated from said place and this has been sore and also I have felt unwell. For the moment antibiotics have cleared this up however the root cause is not sorted  my breast consultant has said that i6t is too late for the liposuction offer but a full revision may cost me my nipple  I wondered if anyone else has had issues so long after getting rid of this critter
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy 5 years on

Posts.Content: Thank you for your reply  My consultant has ruled out recurrence which is great but this new ongoing issue is being referred back to him AGAIN  Really frustrating  Jx
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy 5 years on

Posts.Content: I wore a variety of scarves of all colours and shapes However just as my hair was starting to grow back while I was at the chemo unit getting Herceptin one lady was sporting the most amazing scarf. It was from a motorcycle shop and used under helmets. I really wished I had thought of that. Lots of choice and not expensive. Good luck June
Posts.Title: hats and scarves ?

Posts.Content: Always wise to check. I am 2 years post treatment and my breast is still sore sometimes I had a couple of scares early days and went to have them checked. I was told that some of the cause was the after effect of RT My lump was not painful at diagnosis either and I am reassured by my breast consultant who also made it clear I could see her at any time which I did and was given real reassurance Take care June
Posts.Title: Do you think this is normal ?
